reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s key conditioning move: evaluating how likely mostly-great futures are given survival and “no serious de dicto optimisation pressure.” That baseline is used to motivate the ‘narrow target’/low-by-default probability claim, so if it’s incoherent or misleading it would significantly weaken one main argumentative route (moderately high centrality). However, the critique mostly challenges framing rather than the substantive ‘eutopia is fragile/fussy’ thesis: the paper can reinterpret the baseline as “no additional explicit moral optimisation beyond business-as-usual politics,” and many of the fragility arguments (multiplicativity, moral disagreement, population ethics, digital minds) still go through even under an explicit default-institutional-selection model. So it only partially undercuts the inference and is fairly patchable (modest strength). It is highly relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it pushes toward an explicit model of default governance/power dynamics under capability growth—exactly the sort of cross-link between flourishing arguments and lock-in/power concentration work that Forethought treats as decision-relevant and partly unresolved (high relevance). Overall it’s a useful, constructive reframing critique but not close to a refutation.
title: "Default Optimization Is Not a Neutral Baseline"
